thread.title: Mariners blank Eagles, aim to end season on upswing
thread.title_full: Mariners blank Eagles, aim to end season on upswing

author: news@courierpublicationsllc.com (Staff)
title: Mariners blank Eagles, aim to end season on upswing
text:
Mariners blank Eagles, aim to end season on upswing Oceanside drops recent OT heartbreaker to MCI By Staff | Oct 09, 2015 Photo by: Mark Haskell View More... 
Rockland â€” The Oceanside field hockey team looks to close the regular season on a positive note and appears to be on its way to doing so following the team's homecoming game on Thursday, Oct. 8 against visiting Lincoln Academy of Newcastle. 
The Mariners, playing on senior night, picked a perfect time to turn out their most potent scoring output of the season as they sailed to a convincing 6-0 win over the Eagles, who remain winless. 
Click for photos from this game. 
On the heels of Thursday's win, Oceanside has prevailed in three of its last four games and is entrenched in the 10th and final playoff spot in Class B North. 
The Mariners, with Hermon, Erskine Academy of South China, Waterville and Morse of Morse well behind them in Heal Points, appear to be locked into the postseason, but could potentially move up if they can close out the regular season with a win over host Leavitt on Tuesday, Oct. 13 in Turner. 
On Thursday, the Mariners were paced on offense by Mary Allen (3 goals), Michaela Wright (goal), Makayla Van Blarcom (goal, assist), Krissy McNichol (goal), Erin Dugan (2 assists) and Molly Tobin (assist). 
Lauren Hoppe made three saves in the cage for Oceanside, while Zoey Sewall made 11 saves in goal for Lincoln Academy. The Mariners held a 17-3 lead in shots and a 6-1 edge in penalty corners. 
In the Maine Principals' Association Heal Point Standings for Class B North, Oceanside (5-7-1, 24.2602 points) is 10th, while Gardiner (11-2, 116.0204 points) is first in the 14-team region. The top 10 teams qualify for the playoffs. 
Maine Central Institute 2, Oceanside 1 (OT) 
At Thomas College in Waterville Oct. 6, the Mariners rallied late to tie the game, but the Huskies of Pittsfield persevered as they clawed to their ninth win. MCI led 1-0 at halftime. 
Molly Tobin tied the game with less than a minute remaining in the second half for Oceanside, while Victoria Friend scored in the first half off, an assist from Addi Williams, and another in overtime to win the game for the Huskies. 
Lauren Hoppe made four saves in the cage for Oceanside, while Darrian Leonardi also made a player-save in the tough-luck loss. Mikayla Carr made four saves for MCI. 
The Huskies held a 9-6 edge in shots, while both teams attempted seven penalty corners.
